tei: example from Odyssey, Book I, reused for the Works II Epitaphs. These headpieces have a central circle (3·5 cm in diameter), which usually depicts a figure from the ac- tion of the poem. To either side of the circle are placed objects that evoke the world of the epic, either symbols of war (spears, shields, helmets) or of peace (lyres, goblets, bowls), often enwrapped by fertile vegetation. The whole is contained in a decorative frame. Usually the initials ‘W.K. inv.’ and ‘P.F. sc.’ appear on opposite sides of the foot of the plate. Savage argues persuasively for the close relation between the headpieces
